DOCNAME: CASE OF D. v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 3;Not necessary to examine Art. 2;Not necessary to examine Art. 8;No violation of Art. 13;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The applicant was born in GPE and appears to have lived there most of his life . He is CARDINAL of CARDINAL children . CARDINAL sister and CARDINAL brother moved to GPE in DATE and the rest of the family appears to have followed at unspecified dates . The applicant visited GPE in DATE to try to join his family . During his stay there he was arrested on CARDINAL DATE for possession of cocaine and subsequently sentenced to a DATE term of imprisonment . After DATE , he was paroled for good behaviour and deported on DATE to GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant arrived at FAC , GPE , on DATE and sought leave to enter GPE for DATE as a visitor . He was found at the airport terminal to be in possession of a substantial quantity of cocaine with a street value of QUANTITY ( GBP ) . The immigration officer refused him leave to enter on the ground that his exclusion was conducive to the public good and gave him notice that he would be removed to GPE within DATE .

However , after being arrested and charged , the applicant was remanded in custody and subsequently prosecuted for being knowingly involved in the fraudulent evasion of the prohibition on the importation of controlled drugs of class A. He pleaded guilty at ORG on DATE and was sentenced on DATE to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . He apparently behaved well while in PERSON and was released on licence on DATE . He was placed in immigration detention pending his removal to GPE . Bail was granted by an adjudicator on DATE after the ORG ’s report had been made public .

CARDINAL . ORG In DATE , while serving his prison sentence , the applicant suffered an attack of pneumocystis carinii pneumonia ( " PCP " ) and was diagnosed as HIV ( human immunodeficiency virus)-positive and as suffering from acquired immunodeficiency syndrome ( AIDS ) . The infection appears to have occurred some time before his arrival in GPE .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , the applicant was granted a period of compassionate leave to be with his mother whose air fare to GPE to visit him had been covered by charitable donations .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , immediately prior to his release on licence , the immigration authorities gave directions for the applicant ’s removal to GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG By letter dated DATE , the applicant ’s solicitors requested that the Secretary of ORG grant the applicant leave to remain on compassionate grounds since his removal to GPE would entail the loss of the medical treatment which he was currently receiving , thereby shortening his life expectancy ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) . This request was refused on DATE by the Chief Immigration Officer . In his letter of refusal addressed to the applicant ’s solicitors the Chief Immigration Officer stated :

" In reaching this decision full account was taken of paragraph CARDINAL of ORG and HIV - positive cases . You will be aware that paragraph CARDINAL of this instruction which relates to persons whose applications are for leave to enter the GPE states [ see paragraph CARDINAL of the judgment below ] ... While we are saddened to learn of Mr D [ ... ] ’s medical circumstances we do not accept , in line with ORG , that it is right generally or in the individual circumstances of this case , to allow an AIDS sufferer to remain here exceptionally when , as here , treatment in this country is carried out at public expense , under ORG . Nor would it be fair to treat AIDS sufferers any differently from others suffering medical conditions ... "

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , the applicant applied unsuccessfully to ORG for leave to apply for judicial review of the decision to refuse him leave to enter . On DATE , ORG dismissed his renewed application . It found that section CARDINAL of the Immigration Act DATE drew a distinction between leave to enter and leave to remain . It held that the Chief Immigration Officer had correctly treated PERSON application as an application for leave to enter and was not required to take into account paragraph CARDINAL of the ORG guidelines which applied to applications for leave to remain ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL below ) . As to the applicant ’s argument that ORG acted unreasonably or irrationally in not acceding to the compassionate circumstances of his plea , Sir PERSON stated in his judgment :

" Nobody can but have great sympathy for this applicant in the plight in which he finds himself . If he is to return to GPE it seems that he will be unable to work because of his illness . His expectation of life , if the medical evidence is correct , may well be shorter than it would be if he remained under the treatment that he is receiving in GPE , and in many ways his plight will be great . On the other hand he would not be here if he had not come on a cocaine smuggling expedition in DATE ; and if he had not been imprisoned he would have gone back to GPE , if he had ever come here at all , long before his AIDS was diagnosed . Taking account of the fact that the ORG must give most anxious scrutiny to a decision which involves questions particularly of life expectancy , as this one apparently does , nevertheless I can not find that an argument in this case that the decision of the Chief Immigration Officer was irrational is one that has any hope of success at all . Putting it the opposite way , it seems to me to be one which was well within the bounds of his discretion , and thus is not one with which the ORG can properly interfere . "

CARDINAL . ORG Since DATE , the applicant ’s " CDCARDINAL " cell count has been below CARDINAL . He has been in the advanced stages of the illness , suffering from recurrent anaemia , bacterial chest infections , malaise , skin rashes , weight loss and periods of extreme fatigue .
CARDINAL . ORG By letter dated DATE , PERSON , a consultant doctor , stated :

" His current treatment is AZT QUANTITY . b.d . and DATE nebulised pentamidine , he occasionally takes mystatin pastilles and skin emollients . In view of the fact that [ the applicant ] has now had AIDS for DATE and because this is a relentlessly progressive disease his prognosis is extremely poor . In my professional opinion [ the applicant ’s ] life expectancy would be substantially shortened if he were to return to GPE where there is no medication ; it is important that he receives pentamidine treatment against ORG and that he receives prompt anti - microbial therapy for any further infections which he is likely to develop ... "

CARDINAL . ORG In a medical report provided on DATE , Professor Pinching , a professor of immunology at a GPE hospital , stated that the applicant had suffered severe and irreparable damage to his immune system and was extremely vulnerable to a wide range of specific infections and to the development of tumours . The applicant was reaching the end of the average durability of effectiveness of the drug therapy which he was receiving . It was stated that the applicant ’s prognosis was very poor and limited to DATE on present therapy . It was estimated that withdrawal of the proven effective therapies and of proper medical care would reduce that prognosis to CARDINAL of what would be otherwise expected .

CARDINAL . ORG By letter dated DATE , ORG for LOC informed the doctor treating the applicant in prison that the medical facilities in GPE did not have the capacity to provide the medical treatment that he would require . This was in response to a faxed enquiry of the same date by PERSON , the managing medical officer at FAC . By letter of CARDINAL DATE , PERSON informed ORG contents of the letter from ORG , which had also been sent to ORG on DATE . He stated that the necessary treatment was not available in GPE but was widely and freely available in GPE and requested that due consideration be given to lifting the deportation order in respect of the applicant . By letter dated DATE , ORG for LOC confirmed that the position in GPE had not changed .

CARDINAL . By letter dated DATE , the GPE and ORG informed the applicant ’s representatives that they had consulted their officer on GPE who stated that there was no health care providing for drugs treatment of AIDS .

Results of enquiries made by the Government of the authorities in GPE suggest that there are CARDINAL hospitals in GPE which care for AIDS patients by treating them for opportunistic infections until they are well enough to be discharged , and that an increasing number of AIDS sufferers there live with relatives .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant has no family home or close family in GPE other than , according to information provided by the ORG , a cousin . His mother , who currently lives in GPE , has declared that her age , bad health and lack of resources prevent her from returning to GPE to look after her son if he were to be returned there . She has also stated that she knew of no relatives who would be able to care for him in GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG When granted bail on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) the applicant was released to reside in special sheltered accommodation for AIDS patients provided by a charitable organisation working with homeless persons . Accommodation , food and services are provided free of charge to the applicant . He also has the emotional support and assistance of a trained volunteer provided by ORG , the leading charity in GPE providing practical support , help , counselling and legal and other advice for persons concerned about or having AIDS or HIV infection .

CARDINAL . ORG In a medical report dated DATE PERSON , a consultant in clinical immunology treating the applicant at a GPE hospital , noted that he was at an advanced stage of HIV infection and was severely immunosuppressed . His prognosis was poor . The applicant was being given antiretroviral therapy with " CARDINAL T " and " CARDINALTC " to reduce the risk of opportunistic infection and was continuing to be prescribed pentamidine nebulisers to prevent a recurrence of ORG . Preventative treatment for other opportunistic infections was also foreseen . PERSON noted that the lack of treatment with anti - HIV therapy and preventative measures for opportunistic disease would hasten his death if he were to be returned to GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG The applicant was transferred to an AIDS hospice around DATE for a period of respite care . At DATE there was a sudden deterioration in his condition and he had to be admitted to a hospital on DATE for examination . At the hearing before ORG on DATE , it was stated that the applicant ’s condition was causing concern and that the prognosis was uncertain . According to his counsel , it would appear that the applicant ’s life was drawing to a close much as the experts had predicted ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The regulation of entry into and stay in GPE is governed by LAW DATE . The practice to be followed in the administration of the LAW for regulating entry and stay is contained in statements of the rules laid by the Secretary of ORG before ORG ( " LAW " ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) provides that a person who is not a NORP citizen shall not enter the GPE unless given leave to do so in accordance with the provisions of the LAW . Leave to enter may be granted for a limited or for an indefinite period .

CARDINAL . ORG Under LAW the power to grant or refuse leave to enter is exercised by immigration officers whereas the power to grant leave to remain in GPE is exercised by the Secretary of ORG . These powers are exercisable by notice in writing given to the person affected .

CARDINAL . ORG A person , such as the applicant , who has been refused leave to enter but is physically in the GPE pending his removal and seeks to be allowed to stay there does not fall to be treated as applying for leave to remain . Since no leave to enter had been granted to the applicant , it was right according to the judgment of Sir PERSON in NORP v. Secretary of ORG for ORG , ex parte NORP ( ORG , DATE ) for the immigration officer to treat his application as an application for leave to enter rather than for leave to remain .

CARDINAL . ORG The Immigration and ORG of ORG issued a policy document ( ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) on this subject in DATE . LAW of the guidelines specifies that the fact that a person is suffering from AIDS or is HIV - positive is not a ground for refusing leave to enter or leave to remain if the person concerned otherwise qualifies under LAW . Equally , this fact is not in itself a sufficient ground to justify the exercise of discretion where the person concerned has not met the requirements of the Rules .
The policy guidelines distinguish between applications for leave to enter and applications for leave to remain .

CARDINAL . ORG On applications for leave to enter ( paragraph CARDINAL of the guidelines ) , where the person is suffering from AIDS , the policy and practice is to adhere to the provisions of ORG in the normal way . Where such a person does not qualify under the LAW , entry is refused .

CARDINAL . ORG On applications for leave to remain ( paragraph CARDINAL of the guidelines ) , the application should be dealt with normally on its merits under the applicable Rules . However , there is a discretion outside the Rules which can be exercised in strong compassionate circumstances . Paragraph CARDINAL states that :

" ... there may be cases where it is apparent that there are no facilities for treatment available in the applicant ’s own country . Where evidence suggests that this absence of treatment significantly shortens the life expectancy of the applicant it will normally be appropriate to grant leave to remain . "

CARDINAL . ORG This guide describes the CARDINAL medical strategies available for treating HIV infection and AIDS : using anti - HIV drugs which attack HIV itself to delay or prevent damage to the immune system , treating or preventing opportunistic infections which take advantage of damage to the immune system and strengthening and restoring the immune system . Amongst the first category , several drugs can be used , including AZT ( also known as ORG or its tradename Retrovir ) . This belongs to a family of drugs called nucleoside analogues which inhibit an enzyme produced by HIV called reverse transcriptase ( ORG ) . If ORG is inhibited , HIV can not infect new cells and the build - up of virus in the body is slowed down . However , the existing drugs are only partially effective and at best can only delay the worsening of HIV - related disease rather than prevent it .

CARDINAL . ORG As regards the second category , persons whose immune systems have been significantly damaged are vulnerable to a range of infections and tumours known as opportunistic infections . These commonly include cytomegalovirus ( herpes virus ) , PERSON ’s sarcoma , anaemia , tuberculosis , toxoplasmosis and ORG . ORG is a form of pneumonia which in people infected with HIV may affect the lymph nodes , bone marrow , spleen and liver as well as the lungs . Steps to avoid such infections include taking care with food and drink and prophylactic treatment by drugs . In the case of ORG , which was a common cause of death during DATE of the epidemic and is still one of the commonest AIDS illnesses , options include the long - term taking of antibiotics such as cotrimoxazole and the use of nebulised pentamidine which is intended to protect the lungs .
CARDINAL . ORG In relation to the third category , treatment which strengthens or restores the immune system , research has yet to produce any clear results .
